title.children: Israel says strikes on refugee camp killed senior Hamas leader, Palestinian officials say 50 people dead

image.altText: An Israeli army officer stands inside a narrow underground tunnel holding a firearm.

image.altText: Premier of Tasmania speaking to the House of Assembly.

items.synopsis: Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff categorically declares people in charge of regulatory and oversight bodies were not subject to misconduct allegations by the state's child sexual abuse commission of inquiry. He was responding to a statement made by Independent Upper House MP Meg Webb under parliamentary privilege on Tuesday.

title.children: Tasmanian Premier calls on Meg Webb to apologise, says public servants wrongly named

image.altText: Meg Webb speaks at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Tasmanians had hoped the sexual abuse commission of inquiry would help clean up the culture inside state government institutions and departments, and help to stop child sexual abuse from occurring. Instead, there is a mess — and a lot of questions to be answered, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: Tasmanian government must reassure people their children are safe in state institutions

image.altText: A worker in protective suit and mask holds a pair of scissors above harvested cannabis.

items.synopsis: Demand for Tasmania's special "pot" plants is growing. This farm in southern Tasmania is set to triple its production, but it wants changes to strict advertising rules so it can reveal to customers that its product is local.

title.children: Demand is high for Tasmanian medicinal cannabis, with more than a million scripts written since it was legalised

image.altText: A firefighter hoses grass near a large bushfire

items.synopsis: Firefighters were kept busy overnight, with dozens of bushfire warnings across southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, and more property losses confirmed. Follow live

title.children: Tara blaze downgraded in Queensland as authorities gain the upper hand on grassfires outside Sydney

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Max Tillman It's been confirmed that a Tabulam home has been lost, in north-east of the state. The RFS added that two others have also been damaged. Spokesperson Greg Allan said that one property was destroyed in the Ogilvie Drive fire, but couldn't confirm exactly when it happened. There have also been reports of stock loss around Tenterfield and north-east NSW, he said. "Crews have been able to protect 15 properties within that area. "Our impact teams have been on the ground and will continue to do so over the coming days."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One home lost, two damaged in NSW

children.content: Reporting by Max Tillman
It's been confirmed that a Tabulam home has been lost, in north-east of the state.
The RFS added that two others have also been damaged.
Spokesperson Greg Allan said that one property was destroyed in the Ogilvie Drive fire, but couldn't confirm exactly when it happened.
There have also been reports of stock loss around Tenterfield and north-east NSW, he said.
"Crews have been able to protect 15 properties within that area.
"Our impact teams have been on the ground and will continue to do so over the coming days."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police are asking for information on "several suspicious fires" in Taree. A string of four fires this week kicked off about 6pm on Monday, with reports of a small bush fire on Hughes Street. Patrolling police then spotted a second fire at about 1.30am on Bushland Drive the next day. A third bushfire was located on the same stretch of road a short time later. Then, a fourth fire was noticed behind a property on Hughes Street just before 11.30pm on Tuesday. All four were extinguished by firefighters. Detectives from Manning and Great Lakes Police District believe the fires are suspicious and have commenced inquiries. Police are appealing anyone with info to contact Crime Stoppers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW Police say extinguished Taree fires are suspicious

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: QFES says residents of properties between Drildool Road, Crystal Creek Road, Tara Kogan Road, Upper Humbug Road and Wieambilla Road, including Chinchilla Tara Road, can return with caution. The fire is expected to keep burning for several days, but crews have ruled that it's safe enough for people to assess their properties. This fire has destroyed dozens of properties — many people will be seeing the damage first-hand for the first time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tara fire now at advice level

items.synopsis: Data obtained through Freedom of Information shows most incidents Darwin private security guards responded to in the past year relate to homelessness and alcohol.

title.children: Darwin private security guard interactions highlight key social issues

image.altText: A masked nurse adjusts their blue plastic glove in an operation room.

items.synopsis: Releasing the government's first review into Australia critical infrastructure networks, the home affairs minister says insider threats in hospitals, energy facilities and other essential networks have become one of the greatest threats to Australia's national security.

title.children: 'Disgruntled employees' targeted by foreign spies on dark web, as insider threats become major security focus

image.altText: SES, Police and CFA vehicles and personnel attend to a car crash on a sunny day. One car has an orange tarpaulin on it.

items.synopsis: Brandon Raeburn confused the instructions of his GP and a neurologist and thought he was allowed to drive before having a seizure and causing a fatal crash, a court has heard.

title.children: Driver who caused fatal crash 'confused' by doctor's order not to drive, court hears

items.synopsis: Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin have been on a tear higher in recent weeks, although they're still well down on record highs. Why are they rising and can it be sustained?

image.altText: Israeli forces' flares light up the night sky in northern Gaza Strip

items.synopsis: Hamas's tunnels under Gaza are a prime target for Israel as it expands its ground offensive in the north of the enclave after three weeks of aerial bombardment.

title.children: Ground-level clashes intensify as Israeli military confirms deadly strikes on Gaza refugee camp

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some Australians trapped in Gaza have been advised to go to the Rafah border crossing with Egypt amid reports it may open to some foreign nationals. An unknown number of Australians stuck in the besieged territory have been told that their names are "on the initial list of approved Australians" to cross into Egypt. The ABC has seen an email sent by Australian consular officials which says the border may open to some Australians at 9am local time (6pm AEDT) on Wednesday. The email urges recipients to "seize this opportunity to depart Gaza" if they "deem it safe to do so". Recipients have also been told to take enough food and water to last for at least five hours and expect large crowds. There are 88 Australian citizens, residents, and their families known to be in Gaza. International media have reported that Egypt is set to allow 400 foreign nationals to leave Gaza through its border after a deal was struck with the United States and Israel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Some Australians in Gaza advised to go to Rafah crossing, in hopes it may open

featuredLink.title: 'Seize this opportunity': Australian families in Gaza told to head to Rafah border crossing

children.content: Some Australians trapped in Gaza have been advised to go to the Rafah border crossing with Egypt amid reports it may open to some foreign nationals.
An unknown number of Australians stuck in the besieged territory have been told that their names are "on the initial list of approved Australians" to cross into Egypt.
The ABC has seen an email sent by Australian consular officials which says the border may open to some Australians at 9am local time (6pm AEDT) on Wednesday.
The email urges recipients to "seize this opportunity to depart Gaza" if they "deem it safe to do so".
Recipients have also been told to take enough food and water to last for at least five hours and expect large crowds.
There are 88 Australian citizens, residents, and their families known to be in Gaza.
International media have reported that Egypt is set to allow 400 foreign nationals to leave Gaza through its border after a deal was struck with the United States and Israel.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli military says that nine of its soldiers have died in Gaza fighting, without immediately providing details on where or when, Reuters reports.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli military: nine soldiers killed in Gaza fighting

children.content: The Israeli military says that nine of its soldiers have died in Gaza fighting, without immediately providing details on where or when, Reuters reports.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Isreali settler violence has spiked in the West Bank with 120 Palestinians killed since the war began, the United Nations says. There are now an average of eight incidents per day, compared to three before the October 7 Hamas attack. ABC Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn reports from the village of Qusra in the West Bank, where some of the worst attacks happened. She spoke with Abedalazheim Al Wadi, who said his brother and nephew were gunned down by Israeli settlers, who live in the West Bank illegally according to international law. "My brother has 11 children, his son was about to become a lawyer in a couple of weeks. He had a fiancée and was about to get married, and they kill him," he said. "We live in fear and it's normal for us. Anger and depression is our daily life." Yael Ze'evi, who lives in an illegal Israeli outpost bordering Qusra, denies settlers in her community attack their neighbours or kill Palestinians. "From my point of view, our lives come first. I walk around with a weapon, I have a handgun. If someone comes to me and threatens me, I won't hesitate to shoot him," she said. "We don't enter their areas, we don't enter their villages." Footage from two weeks ago shows Israeli settlers shooting guns in Qusra. Ahed Mahmoud Owdi says his six-year-old niece was shot in the back when they escaped from their house. Three other Palestinians were killed. "We did not provoke them, we had nothing to defend ourselves. We are peaceful. We are not even safe to go to work, we cannot leave our house safely", he said. "There is no safety." Allyson will be doing a Q & A on the blog at 6:30pm AEDT. You can send her your questions by using the 'leave a comment' button at the top of this stream.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Violence has spiked towards Palestinians in the West Bank, the UN says. ABC reports from the ground

image.altText: Nicholas walks along outside in a white button-up shirt.
